intro: Cedrela australis, commonly known as the Brazilian cedar, is a tropical tree native to South America. It belongs to the family Meliaceae and is characterized by its straight, durable wood that is highly valued in the timber industry. The plant typically grows in humid lowland forests and can reach heights of up to 30 meters. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and ovate, while its flowers are small and yellowish-green. Cedrela australis plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing shelter and food for various wildlife species.
